instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I meant to say <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
No green light on the charger, and no fan spin. What should I do?

*** UPDATE *** There is no mag safe for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> & there are no fans present in this model...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: do you have a USB-C meter, it's easier to diagnose the board when you have one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No. But is a good idea. I need to get one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: There literally isn't a light on these chargers. So therefore, no light. Also, there are no fans, thus no fans. Hehe : )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Wow. I have the Power Z dongle and never realized it has a USB-C on it. I was about to buy one, but I already have one. Thanks Alan. I'm going to start using it !

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I might need to add a light and a fan. Since it don't have either.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: whats the voltage and amp is shown on the meter? you have to start measuring...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Alan, this was a little bit of dry Monday morning humor. I was actually referring to the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. There is no light for this model. And this model also has no fans : )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: the light is next to the battery connector. it's very tiny.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I know, thats the battery disconnect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Do you get any voltage at F4700?
What about <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages?

Common failure on this board is <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Ugg... This is a joke post.... I am playing a joke.... There are no mag safe light for this model, and no fan. LOL!
